questions.stem: Equine granulocytic anaplasmosis is also known as:
questions.explanation: Equine granulocytic anaplasmosis is also referred to as equine ehrlichiosis in older literature. It is not EPM (A), equine viral arteritis (C), or influenza (D).

questions.stem: Which statement BEST describes equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A contagious respiratory disease spread by aerosol

options.label: B
options.text: An infectious, noncontagious, seasonal tick‑borne febrile disease of horses

options.label: C
options.text: A nutritional myopathy affecting only young foals

options.label: D
options.text: A chronic metabolic disease with no vector involvement

questions.explanation: The disease is an infectious, noncontagious, seasonal, tick‑borne febrile illness of horses. It is not spread by aerosol (A) and is not a purely metabolic (D) or nutritional myopathy (C).

questions.stem: What is the etiologic agent of equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?
questions.explanation: The etiologic agent is Anaplasma phagocytophilum, a tick‑transmitted bacterium. A. marginale (A) affects cattle, and B. caballi and T. equi (B, D) are piroplasms causing equine piroplasmosis.

questions.stem: The incubation period for equine granulocytic anaplasmosis is approximately:
questions.explanation: The incubation period is typically 8–25 days after tick attachment. The shorter (A, B) and longer (D) intervals do not match the slide content.

questions.stem: Which cells are primarily infected by Anaplasma phagocytophilum in horses?
questions.explanation: A. phagocytophilum primarily infects granulocytes (neutrophils and eosinophils), where morulae can be seen on blood smears. Lymphocytes (A), erythrocytes (C), or hepatocytes (D) are not the main targets.

questions.stem: The pathophysiology of equine granulocytic anaplasmosis most directly leads to which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Vasculitis and interstitial inflammation causing edema, petechiae, ataxia, and hemolytic anemia

options.label: B
options.text: Direct destruction of muscle fibers causing rhabdomyolysis

options.label: C
options.text: Destruction of pancreatic beta cells causing diabetes mellitus

options.label: D
options.text: Demyelination of the spinal cord causing progressive paralysis

questions.explanation: Infection of granulocytes leads to vasculitis and interstitial inflammation, producing edema, petechiae, ataxia, and hemolytic anemia. The mechanisms in B–D describe other disease processes.

questions.stem: Which Ixodes tick species is the PRINCIPAL vector of A. phagocytophilum in the eastern and midwestern USA?
questions.explanation: Ixodes scapularis, the black‑legged or deer tick, is the primary vector in the eastern and midwestern USA, whereas I. pacificus (A) is the main western vector. Dermacentor and Rhipicephalus species (C, D) are not the primary vectors listed.

questions.stem: Under typical conditions, how long must infected ticks feed on a horse to transmit A. phagocytophilum?
questions.explanation: Transmission generally requires infected ticks to feed for about 2–36 hours. Very short or very long feeding times (A, C, D) are not consistent with the described window.

questions.stem: Infection with A. phagocytophilum can result in which hematologic abnormality?
questions.explanation: The infection can result in pancytopenia due to its effects on granulocytes and bone marrow response. Polycythemia (A), isolated eosinophilia (C), or pure red cell aplasia (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Regarding host range and signalment, which statement is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Only donkeys are naturally affected; horses are resistant

options.label: B
options.text: Primarily horses are affected, donkeys can be experimentally infected, and horses ≥ 4 years tend to be more severely affected

options.label: C
options.text: Only foals under 6 months are affected

options.label: D
options.text: Only a specific breed of horse is predisposed

questions.explanation: The disease primarily affects horses, donkeys have been experimentally infected, there is no breed or sex predilection, and horses ≥ 4 years are most severely affected (though foals can be affected). Restriction to donkeys (A), foals only (C), or a specific breed (D) is incorrect.

questions.stem: Which historical findings are commonly reported in horses with equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Lethargy, high fever, anorexia, limb edema, and tick exposure

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic coughing and nasal discharge without fever

options.label: D
options.text: Neurologic signs only with no systemic illness

questions.explanation: Lethargy, high fever, anorexia, limb edema, and a history of tick exposure are classic historical findings. Weight gain (A), isolated respiratory signs (C), or purely neurologic signs (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: On physical examination, which combination of signs is MOST typical of equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Pyrexia, anorexia, depressed mentation, limb edema, mild petechiae/ecchymoses, icterus, ataxia, stiffness or myopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Marked dyspnea and cyanosis without edema

questions.explanation: Common exam findings include pyrexia, anorexia, depression, limb edema (less in young animals), mild petechiae/ecchymoses, icterus, ataxia, stiffness/myopathy, and occasionally arrhythmias or recumbency. The patterns in A, C, and D do not match the syndrome.

questions.stem: Which of the following is LEAST likely to be seen in young animals with equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?
questions.explanation: Limb edema is often absent in young animals, while systemic signs such as fever, anorexia, and depression may still be present. Therefore, edema (A) is least likely in young cases compared with the other signs (B–D).

questions.stem: Which differential diagnoses should be considered for a horse with fever, ataxia, edema, and petechiae suspected of equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Equine viral encephalitis, liver disease with hepatic encephalopathy, purpura haemorrhagica, equine infectious anemia, equine viral arteritis

questions.explanation: Differential diagnoses include viral encephalitis, liver disease with hepatic encephalopathy, purpura haemorrhagica, equine infectious anemia, and equine viral arteritis, all of which can produce fever, neurologic signs, and/or vasculitis. The other options list conditions that do not mimic this systemic febrile vasculitis.

questions.stem: Which laboratory tests can be used to detect A. phagocytophilum in suspected cases?

options.label: B
options.text: Giemsa‑ or Wright‑stained peripheral blood smears, buffy coat smears, indirect fluorescent antibody tests, PCR, and immunohistochemistry

options.label: D
options.text: Serology for equine influenza virus only

questions.explanation: Diagnosis can be supported by stained peripheral or buffy coat smears to visualize morulae, serology (IFA), PCR, and immunohistochemistry. Skin scrapings (A), urine culture (C), or influenza serology (D) are not diagnostic for this agent.

questions.stem: Which pathologic findings are commonly associated with equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Inflammation of small arteries and veins (vasculitis), hemorrhage, edema, petechiae on mucous and serous membranes, and mild inflammatory or interstitial lesions in multiple organs

questions.explanation: Pathologic findings include vasculitis with inflammation of small vessels, hemorrhage, edema, petechiae on mucous and serous membranes, and mild inflammatory or interstitial lesions in heart, CNS, kidneys, spleen, liver, and lung. High lethality with cardiomyopathy (A) or isolated organ lesions (C, D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Which statement about mortality in equine granulocytic anaplasmosis is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Mortality is extremely high in all cases

options.label: B
options.text: Mortality is rare and usually related to secondary complications

options.label: C
options.text: All infected horses become chronic carriers

options.label: D
options.text: Foals always die from the infection

questions.explanation: Mortality is rare and usually due to secondary complications rather than the primary infection itself. It is not uniformly fatal (A, D), and horses do not typically become chronic carriers (C).

questions.stem: Which management approach is recommended for horses with severe ataxia or serious secondary complications?

options.label: C
options.text: Hospitalization for intensive care and monitoring

options.label: D
options.text: Turnout to pasture to encourage movement

questions.explanation: Horses with severe ataxia or significant complications should be hospitalized for close monitoring and intensive care, whereas milder cases can often be managed in the field. Home rest without monitoring (A), euthanasia (B), or unsupervised turnout (D) are not recommended.

questions.stem: In uncomplicated cases, the typical course of equine granulocytic anaplasmosis is that:

options.label: A
options.text: Infection is chronic and progressive over months to years

options.label: B
options.text: Infection is self‑limiting, and horses often recover within 1–2 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Infection resolves within a few hours without treatment

questions.explanation: In many cases the infection is self‑limiting, and horses recover fully in 1–2 weeks, especially with appropriate therapy. Chronic progressive disease (A), seasonal recurrence (C), or resolution within hours (D) are inaccurate.

questions.stem: Which supportive care measures are appropriate in managing equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Stall confinement for ataxic horses, hand‑walking to reduce edema, supportive limb bandages, NSAIDs for fever, IV fluids/electrolytes for debilitated cases, and corticosteroids for severe ataxia

options.label: B
options.text: Strict exercise with no pain control

questions.explanation: Appropriate supportive care includes stall confinement for ataxic horses, hand‑walking to decrease edema, limb bandaging, NSAIDs for antipyresis, IV fluids/electrolytes for debilitated horses, and judicious corticosteroids for severe ataxia. The other options (B–D) do not provide adequate support.

questions.stem: What is the drug of choice for treating equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?
questions.explanation: Oxytetracycline is the drug of choice for treating equine granulocytic anaplasmosis. Penicillin (A), gentamicin (C), and metronidazole (D) are not first‑line for this rickettsial infection.

questions.stem: Which oxytetracycline regimen is recommended in horses with equine granulocytic anaplasmosis?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 mg/kg PO every 24 h for 3 days

options.label: B
options.text: 7 mg/kg IV every 24 h for 3–7 days diluted in saline

options.label: C
options.text: 10 mg/kg IM once daily for 30 days

options.label: D
options.text: 50 mg/kg IV as a single bolus

questions.explanation: A recommended regimen is 7 mg/kg IV every 24 hours for 3–7 days in 0.9% saline, administered slowly. The other dosages and routes (A, C, D) are not supported by the slide.

questions.stem: Which oral tetracycline is commonly used as an alternative or follow‑up therapy after IV oxytetracycline?
questions.explanation: Oral doxycycline (and minocycline) are effective alternatives or follow‑up drugs after IV oxytetracycline. Amoxicillin, enrofloxacin, and cephalexin (A, C, D) are not standard follow‑up choices for this disease.

questions.stem: During oxytetracycline therapy, which parameters should be monitored?
questions.explanation: Because oxytetracycline can affect kidneys and fluid balance, hydration status and renal function should be monitored. Body weight alone (A), liver enzymes (C), or coagulation tests (D) are not the primary concerns noted.

questions.stem: Which statement regarding prognosis and immunity after equine granulocytic anaplasmosis is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Prognosis is poor, and most horses remain lifelong carriers

options.label: B
options.text: Excellent prognosis in uncomplicated cases; many horses develop immunity and are protected from reinfection for at least 2 years, with no carrier or latent state

options.label: C
options.text: Horses become lifelong reservoirs and continue to infect ticks

options.label: D
options.text: Horses never develop protective immunity and are reinfected frequently

questions.explanation: Prognosis is excellent in uncomplicated cases; many horses experience subclinical infections and develop immunity, remaining protected from reinfection for at least 2 years, and there is no known carrier or latent state. Lifelong carriage (A, C) or absence of immunity (D) contradicts the information provided.
